title: 114_hr1778
content: The "Tax Refund Protection Act of 2015" is cited as the short title. It includes regulations for tax return preparers under a new section 7812 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary is required to establish a program to license or certify tax return preparers, regulate them, and ensure they demonstrate good character, reputation, qualifications, and competency. Tax return preparers subject to this section must pay a reasonable fee for licensing or certification. The Secretary will require tax return preparers to disclose fees charged for tax preparation and the average refund processing time for electronically filed returns. Enforcement actions may be taken against incompetent preparers. Tax return preparers subject to this section may face penalties if they are incompetent, disreputable, violate regulations, or intentionally mislead consumers. Preparers not covered by section 330 of title 31, United States Code, are subject to this section. Definitions for tax return preparer and refund anticipation payment arrangement are provided. The table of sections for subchapter A of chapter 80 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting a new item after section 7811. Regulation of tax return preparers under Sec. 7812 applies to returns filed after December 31, 2015. Additionally, regulation of refund anticipation payment instruments is addressed in a new section added to the Consumer Financial Protection Act. The Bureau regulates refund anticipation payment arrangements, requiring tax preparers to disclose fees and differences in refund processing times. The Bureau mandates tax preparers to disclose that a tax refund can be directly deposited into a consumer's account without needing a refund anticipation payment arrangement. If the refund is less than anticipated, the consumer may be responsible for associated fees and interest. Regulations under TILA require tax preparers to comply with certain provisions when entering into refund anticipation payment arrangements. Definitions for tax return preparer and refund anticipation payment arrangement are provided under an open end credit plan. A tax return preparer subject to this section is defined as a preparer not regulated under section 330 of title 31, United States Code. A refund anticipation payment arrangement involves a consumer agreeing to pay a fee or interest upon receipt of their tax refund in exchange for tax preparation services. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act allows for tax refunds to be directly deposited into a designated account or used to pay fees to tax preparers or lenders. A new item is added to the table of contents related to section 1029A. The Dodd-Frank Act allows for tax refunds to be directly deposited or used for fees. Section 1029B regulates refund anticipation payment arrangements, excluding certain tax preparers from certain provisions. Amendments are made to Section 1027(d) of the Act. Amendments are made to Section 1027(d) of the Dodd-Frank Act by adjusting subparagraphs and clauses, including inserting exceptions related to tax return preparers. In paragraph (2), changes are made to subparagraph (A) by simplifying the reference to the previous paragraph. Amendments are made to Section 1027(d) of the Dodd-Frank Act by adjusting subparagraphs and clauses, including inserting exceptions related to tax return preparers. Changes are made to subparagraphs and clauses in paragraph (2) to simplify references to the previous paragraph. Amendments to Section 1027(d) of the Dodd-Frank Act include removing references to paragraph (1)(A) or (1)(B) in subparagraph (D). Section 4 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for split refunds between tax preparers and taxpayers, with limits set by the Secretary. This applies to returns for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Regulations under the Internal Revenue Code and Consumer Financial Protection Act should be coordinated as much as possible.
